Revoluční 1521/84 Ústí nad Labem 400 01 Czech Republic ORLEN UniCRE a.s., Revoluční 1521/84, 400 01 Ústí nad Labem, Czech Republic ⁎ Corresponding author at: ORLEN UniCRE a.s., Biomass department, Areál Chempark, Záluží 1, 400 01 Litvinov, Usti nad Labem, Czechia. ORLEN UniCRE a.s. Biomass department Areál Chempark, Záluží 1 Litvinov Usti nad Labem 400 01 Czechia Nowadays, biodiesel is one of the most common used biofuels. After establishing its use and industrial production, research efforts are focused on developing and optimising catalytic materials. The present work studies the use of different additives for catalyst extrudation of Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides, paying particular attention to catalyst characterisation and activity during rapeseed oil transesterification in a continuous regime (10 MPa and 120–180 °C). According to our results, it is clear that there is a relation between the used extrusion additives and the catalyst properties and activity. The use of glycerol increased catalyst compaction resulting in lower catalytic properties but higher strength values for the Mg-Al and Mg-Fe extrudates (10.7 and 4.5 N/mm, respectively). On the other hand, the use of an additive mixture composed of isopropanol, polyethylene glycol and tetraethyl orthosilicate provides Mg-Fe and Mg-Al extrudates with a solid combination of catalyst activity (70% ester formation at 10 MPa and 180 °C) and good stability, without significant metals leaching Mg < 2.0 mg/Kg and Fe < 0.3 mg/Kg. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mixed oxides Biodiesel Extrudates Transesterification 1 . Introduction The European Union Directives related to energy uses (2018/2001, 2009/28/EC and 2009/30/EC) pursue a decrease of energy imports, promoting the use of energy from renewable sources. In this way, biofuels play a significant role, replacing petroleum-based fuels, such as diesel, gasoline or kerosene. One of the most common biofuels in our era is the biodiesel or FAME (Fatty Acid Methyl Ester), obtained by transesterification of triglycerides under catalytic conditions [1]. During the last years, biodiesel research has been focused on the transesterification of different oleaginous feedstocks (including waste cooking oils) and catalytic conditions [2–6]. Typically, the transesterification reaction is catalysed at a homogenous state. However, the use of liquid catalysts (such as an alcoholic solution of KOH or NaOH) represents several difficulties for a possible scaling up (i.e. reuse of catalyst, saponification reactions or mandatory cleaning step for products). Thus, the current research related to biodiesel is looking for new materials that can be used as heterogeneous catalysts [7–10]. The mixed oxides, as Mg-Al and Mg-Fe, are getting high interest as new catalytic materials. These materials, synthesized from layered double hydroxides (LDH's) [11] by calcination (400–600 °C), are commonly naming by the following formula: [ M 1 − x 2 + N x 3 + ( O H − ) 2 ] X + [ ( A n − ) x / n · z H 2 O ] X − where M 2 + represents a divalent metallic cation (e.g. Mg), N 3 + represents another trivalent metallic cation (e.g. Fe or Al), A n − is an intercalating inorganic/organic anion ( C O 3 2 − , N O 3 − , S O 4 2 − amongst others), z correspond to the water molecules in the structure and x is the molar ratio of the metallic cation [12–14]. The structure and chemical properties of the mixed oxides catalysts mainly depend on the combination and ratio of metallic ions present in the LDH's [15]. Previous studies have shown that those calcined LDH's, i.e. mixed oxides, are significantly catalytic active for the esterification and transesterification reactions. In this sense, high conversion and yields (always >90%) of triglycerides have been reported by several authors using Mg-Al, Mg-Ca and Mg-Fe mixed oxides from different oleaginous feedstocks, such as rapeseed oil, soybean oil or fats [10,16–18]. After confirming the activity of these materials as catalysts, the next step involves the upscaling of the process, going from the catalyst in powder form and an autoclave reactor to the catalyst in extrudates form and a fixed bed continuous reactor [19,20]. There are not a significant number of references focussed on transesterification of triglycerides in continuous regime with those calcined LDH's as a catalyst. This number is even lower in the case of mixed oxides in extrudates form [21,22]. Nevertheless, the available studies show interesting results, as a 65% of fatty acid conversion obtained over Ca-Zn-Al mixed oxides (65 °C, 0.1 MPa and methanol oil ratio 30:1) [14], a 92% of ester yield over calcined Zn-Al LDH's (140 °C, 1.7 MPa, the volume of methanol per volume of oil 1 and WHSV 1 h − 1) [23] or a yield to the ester of 66% in the case of Mg-Al mixed oxides (115 °C, 4.0 MPa) [24]. In terms of stability, the available results seem to be good as well, without a significant decrease in FAME conversion after 500 h of continuous operation over KF/Ca-Mg-Al [25,26]. To the best of our knowledge, there is no available significant number of studies about mixed oxides catalysts extrudates using different extrusion additives and their catalytic performance during transesterification reaction. This study is a previous step of the application sphere for these catalysts at an industrial scale. In this work, we build on our previous research [10,24,27,28] by studying eight mixed oxides extrudates for the transesterification of rapeseed oil at 10 MPa and 120–180 °C in a continuous regime, paying attention to the extrusion additives and their effect on catalyst properties, activity and stability. Our study allows us to define the best extrusion additive and describe the best catalytic behaviour observed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst synthesis and extrudation The Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides were synthesised by co-precipitation in a 5 L batch type glass reactor (Syrris Globe, Syrris Ltd). This unit has a propeller stirrer, a two-piston pump (syringe-type), and controllers for pH and temperature. The catalyst precursor consisted of a metal nitrates solution (cMg+Fe/Al=1 mol/dm3) at molar ratio Mg/M3+ = 3, was continuously added into de reactor together with a basic solution (K2CO3/KOH – CK(OH=2 mol∙dm−3, CK2CO3=0.2 mol∙dm−3), used to maintain the pH stable. The reaction mixture was kept at synthesis conditions for 1 h (60 °C, pH 9.5, 250 rpm). Then, the product resulted was filtered by the press-filtration method, using filter-press with S15N filtration paper plate (Hobra, s.r.o.). Finally, the product paste was washed with deionised water (till pH 7.0 in wash waters, confirming potassium leaching) and dried at 65 °C for 12 h. For the extrudation procedure, 50 g of the synthesised precursor was inserted into a kneader HKV-1 (IKA) with the extrusion additives. Table 1 shows the used extrusion additives for catalyst extrudation. The extrudation mixture was kneaded at 30 Hz of frequency for 10 min. Then, the resulted thick paste was introduced into a single screw extruder with a 2.5 mm diameter circle slot matrix (CALEVA VDE). Finally, the Mg-Al or Mg-Fe extrudates were calcined at 450 and 500 °C, respectively, obtaining the corresponding mixed oxides. From the technical point of view, the mixtures of PEG+TEOS on Mg-Fe mixed oxides and Glyc-TEOS on Mg-Al mixed oxides were not suitable for catalyst extrudation, giving place to several mechanical problems during catalysts synthesis. That was the reason why those catalysts were not possible to test. 2.2 Catalyst characterisation The catalyst composition of Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides was determined by inductively coupled plasma – optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES - Agilent 725, USA). The catalyst samples were dissolved in HNO3 as pre-treatment. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed with a Bruker AXS D8-Advance diffractometer, using Cu-Kα radiation with a secondary graphite monochromator. The diffraction intensity was measured from 5 to 70 ° (step size of 0.02 °; step time of 0.5 s). The patterns were evaluated by using the Diffrac.Eva software with the Powder Diffraction File database (PDF 4 + 2018, International Centre for Diffraction Data). The crystallite size of the mixed oxides was calculated using the Scherer equation, which is defined as follow: (1) D = 0.9 λ / ( β c o s θ ) where D is the average crystallite size (mm), 0.9 is the value used as shape factor, λ is the wavelength of Cu-Kα radiation, β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and θ is the diffraction angle (43 °). The N2-adsorption isotherms, the specific surface area (SBET) and the micro-pore size distribution were measured on an Autosorb iQ (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL, USA) at the boiling point of liquid nitrogen (77 K). The catalyst samples were degassed at 110 °C in a vacuum for 24 h as pre-treatment. The pore size distribution was determined according to Non-local density functional theory (NLDFT). The macro-pore size distribution was determined by AutoPore IV 9510 porosimeter (Micromeritics, USA). The catalyst samples were degassed in a vacuum at 120 °C before analysis. The Hg-porosimetry was performed in a range of pressure of 0.7 kPa to 413 MPa (10 s of equilibrium at each pressure stage). The acid/base properties were measured by Temperature programmed desorption (TPD NH3/CO2 respectively) on an AutoChem 2950 HP instrument (Micromeritics, USA) with a Thermal conductivity detector (TCD). As pre-treatment, the catalyst samples were degassed at their calcination temperature (450 °C) in He (flowrate of 25 mL/min). The adsorption of NH3/CO2 was carried out at 40 °C for 30 min, respectively. On the other hand, the desorption procedure was performed by heating the samples from 40 to 800 °C. The standard tests for radial crush strength of extruded catalyst were performed by the UMZ-3 K Micro-Epsilon device as the ASTM (D6175) norm. For this mechanical testing, the extrudates were cut to 2.5 mm length with a length to diameter ratio > 1.0 (the extrudates diameter decreased during calcination to approximately 2.2 mm). Then, the extrudates were placed between the anvils of the compression testing device, in flat position against the face of the anvil and were crushed radially. The crush strength for the catalyst extrudates was calculated using the following formula: (2) X = F / L where X is the crush strength of the extrudate per millimetre (N/mm), F is the force necessary to crush the extrudates (N), and L is the length of the extrudate along its cylindrical axis (mm). 2.3 Experimental setup and catalytic tests The transesterification reaction of rapeseed oil with methanol was carried out in a bench-scale unit (Parr Instrument, USA) using a stainless steel reactor with dimensions of 20 mm of inner diameter and 820 mm of length. For each experiment, 5 g of catalyst extrudates (2 mm length) was mixed with fine carborundum (SiC – 0.1 mm) in a volume ratio of 1:1 to minimise the wall-flow effect and improve the heat transfer inside the reactor. The catalyst bed was situated in the middle part of the reactor, filling the rest of the reactor volume with gross carborundum (SiC – 1–2 mm). Before each reaction, the catalyst was calcinated at 450 °C (100 °C/h) for 3 h under a nitrogen flow of 10 L/h at 10 MPa. Then, the reactor temperature was decreased to 120 °C. Once reached reaction conditions, the liquid feed started (Rapeseed oil 10 g/h and methanol 9 g/h). After 30 h of processing, the unit reached the steady-state. From that moment, the liquid product was sampled every 6 h. During the reaction, the temperature reaction was changed to 150, 180 and again to 120 °C. The time-lapse was always the same for each step, 30 h. These operation conditions (10 MPa and 120–180 °C), more severe than standard transesterification (0.1 MPa and 65 °C), were used to ensure reaction in a liquid phase and increase reaction rate in the continuous regime and using heterogeneous catalysts. For all the liquid samples, the methanol in excess was removed by distillation, and the ester phase (EP) was separated from the glycerol one by decantation. The content of methyl esters in the ester phase was determined by GC analysis (Agilent 7890A – Agilent technologies, USA – FID detector and biodiesel capillary column, Restek Co., USA – 15 m, 0.32 mm ID, 0.10 µm MET). For this analysis, 5 µl of the EP was mixed with 60.8 µl of MSTFA (p.a., Sigma Aldrich), 100 µl of pyridine (p.a. Lach:ner), and 4 ml of cyclohexane (p.a., Lach:ner). The ester yield was calculated as follow: (3) Y e s t e r = ( m e s t e r / m e s t e r p h a s e ) · 100 where mester is the mass of the ester in the ester phase, calculated from the calibration curve, and mester phase correspond to the mass of the total ester phase. Analogous to catalyst samples, the metal content in the liquid samples was analysed by ICP-OES (Agilent 725, USA). Before analysis, each liquid sample was mixed with p-toluenesulfonic acid (weight ratio 10:1) and calcined at 500 °C. Finally, the resulted ashes were dissolved using H2SO4 and analysed by ICP-OES. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization XRD analysis was used to identify the main crystalline phases of mixed oxides extrudates. Fig. 1 shows the XRD spectra of each Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates, indicating the chemicals used as extrusion additives during extrudation (indicated after the catalyst type). From XRD diagrams (Fig. 1), it is clear the presence of the MgO crystalline phase on mixed oxides, which manifested as intense diffraction lines at 2 theta of 35.6, 43.3, and 62.8 ° (PDF 03–0998) [29]. The absence of any other diffraction lines suggests a successful mixed oxides formation during catalyst synthesis. The general appearance of XRD spectra points to a homogeneous distribution of aluminium oxides (Al2O3)/iron oxides (Fe2O3) in the MgO lattice [30]. We confirmed this fact by determining the lattice parameter "a" (cation-cation distance) for the diffraction 200, which had a value of 4.1759 ± 0.0025 Å and 4.2132 ± 0.0014 Å for Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides, respectively, similar to the MgO, 4.2130 Å. The differences between the lattice "a" parameter of Mg-Al mixed oxides regarding the case of MgO were due to the differences in the effective ion-diameters of Al and Mg (53 and 72 pm, respectively). In the Mg-Fe mixed oxide, the lattice "a" parameter was similar to the MgO, although the effective ion-diameter of Fe is slightly lower than the Mg one (65 pm) [31]. A detailed analysis of the diffraction peak at 2 theta 35.6 ° (PDF 71–1232) reveals the presence of spinels groups on the Mg-Fe mixed oxides (MgFe2O4). The authors' previous experience has related these spinel groups' presence in mixed oxides catalysts with a lower catalyst activity during transesterification [28]. Table 2 shows other parameters such as crystallinity and the composition of mixed oxides extrudates. Remaining component corresponds to oxygen of the mixed oxide. The crystallinity of Mg-Al mixed oxides was similar for all the samples (45.0 52.0%), independently of the used extrusion additive. In contrast, the crystallinity of Mg-Fe mixed oxides changed depending on the mixture of chemicals used for extrudation, obtaining the lower crystallinity values when glycerol was used (25.0 29.2%). The crystallite size (D), estimated using the Scherrer equation [28,32], resulted in values of 4.5–4.8 nm and 6.3–6.9 nm for Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides. There was not an apparent effect of the chemicals used as an extrusion additive and the size of crystallites. Regarding the catalysts composition, both mixed oxides showed a similar molar ratio between metals (Mg/Al or Mg/Fe), with a value in a range of 2.8 3.2 mol:mol. Si was not detected on mixed oxides, except in cases where TEOS was used as an extrusion additive, staying on the structure after calcination. TGA analysis was used to evaluate the thermal stability of mixed oxides extrudates. The released gases (typically H2O and CO2) were analysed by using a mass spectrometer. Fig. 2 shows TGA analysis for Mg-Al and Mg-Fe LDH's and its first derivate to analyse catalyst thermal-degradation temperatures better. In general, the thermal degradation of the LDH takes place in three different steps or mass decreases [10]. The first step occurs at a range of 30–170 °C [33], where most of the water absorbed from atmospheric humidity is released from the LDH structure. At higher temperatures (220 310 °C) occurs the release of water bounded as an OH-group on the metals [34]. These two mass decreases correspond to approximately 50% of the total weight of the catalyst. Finally, at higher temperatures (> 350 °C) occurs the thermal decomposition of the LDH structure resulting in the formation of mixed oxides [30]. The addition of extrusion additives did not mean a significant change in the TGA, leaving the catalyst structure during the first step of thermic degradation. The exception of this behaviour was observed in samples with glycerol due to its higher boiling point (290 °C). N2-physisorption and Hg-Porosimetry were used to analyse the pore volume distribution and specific surface area of mixed oxides structure. A higher volume of mesopores is related to a higher activity of catalyst during transesterification [35]. Fig. 3 shows N2-physisorption analysis of Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates. Fig. 3a and Fig. 3b clearly show that Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates have type IV physisorption isotherms, typical for a mesoporous catalytic structure [36]. The hysteresis loops seem to be H2-H3 type in all cases, indicating a neck-like and groove pores structure [37]. This fact makes sense considering that the extrudation process might result in this internal structure [38]. According to these results, it seems the different extrusion additives used for extrudation did not affect the N2-adsorption isotherms or the hysteresis loops appearance, always obtaining the same mesoporous structure. The results from Fig. 3c and Fig. 3d confirms this fact, observing a predominance of mesopores on catalyst structure. Moreover, almost all mixed oxides extrudates showed similar pore volume distribution, except those in which glycerol was used as an extrusion additive. Glycerol on the extrusion additives mixture produced higher low-sized pores (10–20 nm) but always in the mesoporous range. This fact might be related to better compaction of extrudates, which could decrease the crystallinity of the catalysts samples (Table 2) when glycerol was used. Table 3 shows the specific surface and pore volumes for Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates. From the results of Table 3, it is clear that the extrudation process, together with the chemical used during extrusion, did affect the BET surface of the mixed oxides [38]. For Mg-Al mixed oxides extrudates, the use of any other extrusion additives mixture than IPrOH-Glyc produced a significant decrease in BET surface, with the lowest value of 232.4 m2/g for PEG-TEOS. Similar behaviour was observed for Mg-Fe mixed oxides with a lower BET surface (150 m2/g) than Mg-Al mixed oxides (240 m2/g), obtaining higher BET surface values when glycerol was used in the mixture of extrusion additives. In the case of pore volume determined by N2-adsorption, there was not an effect of extrusion additives on pore volumes, with similar mesoporous volume for Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates. Hg-porosimetry allows a better approach for the analysis of bigger size pores. Fig. 4 shows meso‑ and macropore distribution on mixed oxides extrudates surface measured by Hg-porosimetry. In the data of Fig. 4, it can be seen that the extrusion additives affect the catalyst pore volume distribution in a different way depending on the mixed oxides type. For Mg-Al, all the catalyst extrudates shower similar pore volume distribution divided in two ranges of pore diameters: from 0 to 100 nm and from 1000 to 10,000 nm, which correspond to meso‑ and macropores, respectively. For this type of mixed oxides, the use of iPrOH-TEOS or iPrOH-PEG seems to be the most optimal extrusion additive mixtures for extrudation, increasing the number of mesopores. For Mg-Fe mixed oxides, the pore volume distribution changed depending on the used extrusion additives. In this way, glycerol promotes better compaction of extrudates resulting in a lower pore diameter range (from 1 to 30 nm). These results are in strong agreement with the N2-physisorption results of Fig. 3d. The use of other extrusion additives mixture gave place to larger size porous, but always in the range of mesopores. Compared with Mg-Al mixed oxides, the volume of macro-pores was not significant for Mg-Fe mixed oxide extrudates. According to our results, it seems to be a relationship between the lengths of the extrusion additive molecule and pore size on catalyst structure. It is necessary to deep in this point to describe better the role of extrudates additives on pores size distribution. NH3 and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD- NH3/CO2, respectively) characterise the acid and basic sites on the mixed oxides. Fig. 5 shows the TPD-CO2 and TPD-NH3 profiles for each Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates. According to Fig. 5a and Fig. 5b, it is clear that the used extrusion additive mixture during extrudation plays a relevant and different role in the distribution of the basic sites of mixed oxides extrudates. In Mg-Al mixed oxides, all the extrudates showed a TCD-CO2 profile with two desorption peaks at different temperatures, corresponding to weak (< 200 °C) and strong (200 350 °C) basic sites [39, 40]. For these mixed oxides extrudates, glycerol promotes the formation of a higher amount of weak basic sites. On the other hand, using iPrOH-PEG-TEOS or PEG-TEOS as extrusion additives increased the strong basicity of the catalyst extrudates, which manifested in the higher amount of strong basic sites. Mg-Fe mixed oxides showed similar basic sites distribution as Mg-Al with two desorption peaks, corresponding to weak and strong basic sites. However, the effect of the extrusion additive on catalyst basicity was different. From the results in Fig. 5a, it can be seen that using iPrOH as an extrusion additive promoted the amount of strong basic sites on catalysts extrudates (iPrOH-PEG-TEOS). On the other hand, Fig. 5c and Fig. 5d showed the effects of extrusion additives on acid sites distribution. For Mg-Al mixed oxides extrudates, there was no significant dependence on acid sites distribution and extrusion additives. Nevertheless, similar to basic sites, glycerol produced the highest amount of weak acid acids (< 200 °C). For Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates, the behaviour was different. In this case, it was observed an effect of extrusion additive and the acid sites distribution. The mixture of iPrOH+PEG seems to be the most optimal, promoting strong acid sites on the catalyst surface. The presence of strong basic and acid sites is directly related to the catalyst activity during triglycerides transesterification [41,42]. Table 4 shows the amount and density of basic and acid sites on mixed oxide extrudates. The results in Table 4 confirmed the basic and acid sites characterisation data from Fig. 5. Mg-Al mixed oxides extrudates showed a higher amount of basic sites (Mg-Al: 0.91±0.15 mmol/g; Mg-Fe: 0.69±0.08 mmol/g), but lower density than Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates. The use of glycerol in Mg-Al mixed oxides extrudates promoted the formation of basic sites (1.11 mmol /g for iPrOH-Glyc), and in the same way, isopropanol promoted the number of basic sites for Mg-Fe. For acid sites, the results are similar to the described in Fig. 5. The extrusion additive mixture of PEG-TEOS for Mg-Al mixed oxides increased the density of acid sites. The standard test for radial crush strength was used to analyse the physical properties of catalyst extrudates. After observing the effect of extrusion additives on catalyst properties, a relation between those extrusion additives and catalyst extrudates strength properties is expected. Table 5 shows the average value of radial crush strength (ASTM D6175) for fresh and used catalyst samples. According to the results of radial crush strength, it is clear that the extrusion additives play a crucial role in the extrudation process [21]. For this set of extrudates, only the catalyst samples using Glyc or iPrOH as extrusion additives for extrudation (i.e. iPrOH-Glyc, iPrOH-PEG, Glyc-TEOS) showed significant strength values to compression. This point was especially true for Mg-Al mixed oxides, with the highest values (up to 10.7 N/mm for Mg-Al (IPrOH-Glyc)). It was not possible to determine this value for all the catalyst extrudates. Nevertheless, all of them showed good enough values to avoid breaking during the reaction, which is the essential point to consider [20]. These results are in strong concordance with the previous catalyst characterisation analysis, where glycerol seemed to promote better compaction of extrudates, resulting in lower pore diameters (from 1 to 30 nm). No significant differences were found on radial crush strength due to reaction, observing similar values for both types of catalysts (fresh and used). 3.2 Catalytic activity of transesterification From the catalyst characterisation results, it is possible to claim that the used extrusion additive mixture plays a significant role in pore volume distribution, catalyst acid-base properties and radial crush strength. This fact surely means an effect on catalyst activity during triglycerides transesterification to biofuels. Fig. 6 shows the conversion of RSO in terms of ester amount. Table 6 shows the mean values of ester amount (%) for each set of operating conditions to analyse results better. First of all, it is clear that operating temperature plays a significant role in the catalyst activity, obtained the highest triglycerides conversion at the highest temperature, for these experiments, 180 °C. At the same temperature, the activity depended on the extrusion additive mixture used for extrudation. Thus, using an extrusion additives mixture composed of iPrOH-PEG-TEOS seem to be the most optimal for both mixed oxides extrudates, with a range of values from 35 to 85 wt.%. and 30–75 wt.% for Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides, respectively. These results strongly agree with catalyst characterisation, obtaining the best catalyst performance combining a high presence of mesopores and strong basic sites. The differences in activity between mixed oxides types could be due to the slightly higher presence of spinel groups on Mg-Fe than in Mg-Al mixed oxides and catalyst performance. On the other hand, the lower values for ester yield were obtained when glycerol was used for extrudation. This point makes sense considering that glycerol favoured the catalyst compaction, affecting the catalyst crystallinity and producing smaller pore diameters and weaker acid/basic sites. The catalyst activity was verified by studying the catalyst stability during transesterification, particularly for those mixed oxides extrudates that showed higher values of ester amount, i.e. Mg-Al and Mg-Fe extruded using iPrOH+PEG and iPrOH+PEG+TEOS. For this purpose, we evaluated the metal leaching from catalyst extrudates by a two terms study. First, the metal content (i.e. Mg, Al or Fe) of the reaction liquid products were analysed, consisted of a mixture of ester and glycerol phases. Later, the total amount of metals leached was evaluated to determine the catalyst stability during the transesterification reaction. Fig. 7 shows the metal content of liquid products from transesterification using Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides with iPrOH-PEG and iPrOH-PEG-TEOS as extrusion additives. According to Fig. 7, it seems that operating temperature plays the most relevant role in metal leaching from catalyst extrudates. This fact makes sense considering that high-temperature reactions are commonly related to higher decreases of catalyst activity due to coke formation. For Mg-Al mixed oxides extrudates, Mg was the most leached metal during transesterification reaction at 180 °C, with leaching values from 4.2 to 16.2 mg/kg, when iPrOH+PEG or iPrOH+PEG+TEOS were used as extrusion additives, respectively. This result agrees with previous works of the authors [10, 43], indicating higher leaching of Mg than Al or Fe on mixed oxides type catalysts. The metal leaching phenomena of Mg-Al mixed oxides (Mg: 4.2 to 16.2 mg/kg; Al: 0.8 2.9 mg/kg) might explain the higher ester yields obtained at the end of the experiments, despite using the same operating conditions already tested (150 °C). No significant metal leaching was detected for Mg-Fe mixed oxides, with values lower than 2.0 mg/kg for Mg or 0.5 mg/kg for Fe. According to these results, Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudation using iPrOH+PEG+TEOS showed the best catalytic behaviour with a solid combination of catalyst activity (up to 75% of ester yield) and stability, indicated by poor metals leaching. 4 Conclusions This work studied the use of Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxide extrudates, using different combinations of extrusion additives, for the transesterification of rapeseed oil at a continuous regime (10 MPa, 120–150–180 °C) for more than 160 h. The extrusion additive mixtures affect the overall catalyst properties differently, especially the pore volume and the acid/basic sites distribution, which plays a significant role in catalyst activity during transesterification. In this sense, the use of glycerol increased catalysts compaction, resulting in extrudes with lower crystallinity (25.0–29.0%), smaller pore sizes (10–20 nm), weak acid and basic sites (< 200 °C), but higher strength values (9.9–10.7 N/mm). On the other hand, using an extrusion additives mixture composed of isopropanol, polyethene glycol, and tetraethyl orthosilicate showed the best catalyst properties, resulting in a good combination of mesopores (10–100 nm) availability and a high presence of strong basic sites (200–350 °C). In strong agreement with the catalyst characterisation, Mg-Fe mixed oxides extrudates (iPrOH+PEG+TEOS) showed the highest catalytic activity and stability. This point means a solid combination of high conversion of triglycerides into esters and no significant metals leaching (Mg < 2.0 mg/Kg and Fe < 0.3 mg/Kg) for more than 160 h. Thus, according to this work, it is possible to claim that Mg-Fe extruded using iPrOH+PEG+TEOS is a promising catalytic material to produce biodiesel in a continuous regime. However, it is necessary to optimise the extrudation process to improve extrudates physical properties. This fact is strongly related to the application sphere of this catalytic material, in line with new and ambitious regulations related to the use and promotion of green and renewable energy. coredata.dc:description: Nowadays, biodiesel is one of the most common used biofuels. After establishing its use and industrial production, research efforts are focused on developing and optimising catalytic materials. The present work studies the use of different additives for catalyst extrudation of Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides, paying particular attention to catalyst characterisation and activity during rapeseed oil transesterification in a continuous regime (10 MPa and 120–180 °C). According to our results, it is clear that there is a relation between the used extrusion additives and the catalyst properties and activity. The use of glycerol increased catalyst compaction resulting in lower catalytic properties but higher strength values for the Mg-Al and Mg-Fe extrudates (10.7 and 4.5 N/mm, respectively). On the other hand, the use of an additive mixture composed of isopropanol, polyethylene glycol and tetraethyl orthosilicate provides Mg-Fe and Mg-Al extrudates with a solid combination of catalyst activity (70% ester formation at 10 MPa and 180 °C) and good stability, without significant metals leaching Mg < 2.0 mg/Kg and Fe < 0.3 mg/Kg.
coredata.dc:title: Triglycerides transesterification over Mg-Al and Mg-Fe mixed oxides catalysts: Influence of extrusion additives
